title: 112_hr3180
content:
The Act is titled the "U.S.S. Cruiser Olympia Commemorative Coin Act." The U.S.S. Cruiser Olympia, the world's oldest steel warship afloat, is a symbol of America's emergence as a global power. It is a National Historic Landmark and was the flagship of the Asiatic Squadron during the Spanish-American war. The U.S.S. Cruiser Olympia, commissioned in 1895, became famous as the first victor of the Spanish-American War under Commodore George Dewey's command. It destroyed the Spanish squadron and shore batteries in Manila Bay on May 1, 1898, accepting the surrender of the Spanish forces. The U.S.S. Cruiser Olympia, commissioned in 1895, was the first victor of the Spanish-American War under Commodore George Dewey's command. It served in various locations during the early twentieth century and became the flagship of the American fleet during World War I. In 1921, it carried the first American unknown soldier from France to Washington, DC for interment at Arlington National Cemetery. The ship was decommissioned in Philadelphia in 1922 and has remained there since. The U.S.S. Cruiser Olympia, commissioned in 1895, was the first victor of the Spanish-American War under Commodore George Dewey's command. It is permanently docked at Penn's Landing, Philadelphia, open for public viewing, and is one of only four warships representative of the Spanish-American war period in the world. The Friends of the Cruiser Olympia is a non-profit organization dedicated to restoring and preserving the ship, relying on funds from members, donations, and sponsorships for its mission. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 silver coins in honor of the U.S.S. Cruiser Olympia. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the courage, pride, sacrifice, duty, and history of the U.S.S. Cruiser Olympia. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2016", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant parties and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities during the calendar year starting on January 1, 2016. The Secretary is authorized to sell these coins. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount.

SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. All sales of coins issued under this Act include a $10 surcharge per coin, with the surcharges going to the Friends of the Cruiser Olympia for restoration purposes. The Comptroller General has the right to audit the expenditures related to these surcharges. No surcharge may be included if it would exceed the limit for commemorative coins in a calendar year. The issuance of the coin would be subject to the commemorative coin program issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance for this.
